title: Human race is always close to major disasters due to human-animal-bird conflicts: Dr Ishwar Gilada - Deccan Herald
summary:
Human Race Faces Risks of Major Disasters from Human-Animal Conflicts, Warns Expert

Date: 15 January 2025, Source: Unknown

Dr. Ishwar Gilada emphasizes the ongoing threat of zoonotic diseases, highlighting recent bird flu cases and the need for awareness and preparedness.

  • Zoonotic infections have a history of causing outbreaks, including Ebola and COVID-19.
  • Dr. Gilada warns of the dangerous trend in animal-to-human transmission of viruses.
  • The recent H5N1 bird flu cases in the USA and Cambodia have raised global health concerns.
  • H5N1 has a high mortality rate among humans, yet human-to-human transmission is rare.
  • Preparedness for pandemics must extend to all forms of disasters, both natural and man-made.
“No doubt that human infection with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) A, H5N1 virus has high potential for severe respiratory infection as well as high mortality.” - Dr. Ishwar Gilada

Dr. Gilada insists on the importance of scientific communication and urges the public to remain calm amidst the panic.
newTitle: Human Race Faces Risks of Major Disasters from Human-Animal Conflicts, Warns Expert

title: HMPV vs other respiratory viruses: Doctor sheds light on key differences - Hindustan Times
summary:
From influenza to covid-19, here’s how HMPV is different from other respiratory viruses.

Publication Date: Jan 15, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

The Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) has symptoms similar to the flu and cold, can be mild in healthy adults, but severe in children and older adults. Recently, it has garnered attention in India.

  • HMPV was first identified in 2001 and is known to cause respiratory infections, particularly in vulnerable populations.
  • It accounts for 4-16% of acute respiratory infections globally.
  • Unlike COVID-19, HMPV does not have a documented outbreak pattern.
  • Comparatively, influenza is preventable via vaccines, whereas HMPV lacks such preventive measures.
  • HMPV shares transmission methods with SARS-CoV-2 but is less contagious.
“While HMPV and SARS-CoV-2 share a mode of transmission—via respiratory droplets—the latter is much more contagious and has a broader spectrum of symptoms.” - Dr. Maheshkumar Lakhe

In conclusion, understanding the distinctions between HMPV and other respiratory viruses is crucial for public awareness and health management.
newTitle: Key Differences Between HMPV and Other Respiratory Viruses Explained by Doctor

title: Self-Care Behavior Based on Knowledge of Hypertensive Patients: A Cros | VHRM - Dove Medical Press
Are chips and ice cream your child's favourite treats? Study says they could cause buck teeth - Hindustan Times
summary:
Children Love Chips and Ice Cream, But These 'Simple' Snacks Are Dangerous for Your Kids' Dental Health

Date: Jan 15, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

Children often gravitate towards ultra-processed foods like chips and ice cream, which while tasty, carry health risks. A recent study reveals that such diets may lead to deformities in jaw structure, particularly in younger children.

  • Ultra-processed foods are high in calories, sugar, and salt.
  • These foods require less chewing, leading to underdeveloped jaw muscles.
  • Study shows children with high UFP diets have smaller jaw sizes.
  • Misalignment of teeth, notably buck teeth, can result from this diet.
  • Research indicates that solid, fibrous foods promote healthy jaw development.
“Chewing solid, fibrous foods is essential for healthy jaw development. These foods help prevent malocclusion, or misalignment of teeth,” Dr. Laura Marques Martinez.

The findings stress the importance of balanced diets for children's dental health to avoid long-term issues.
newTitle: The Dental Risks of Children Eating Chips and Ice Cream

title: Suspected outbreak of Marburg virus kills 8 in Tanzania: WHO - The Hindu
summary:
Suspected Outbreak of Marburg Virus Claims 8 Lives in Tanzania

Date: January 15, 2025
Source: WHO

A suspected outbreak of the Marburg virus in northwest Tanzania has infected 9 people, resulting in 8 fatalities, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

  • The outbreak was reported in Kagera region of Tanzania, with symptoms including headache, high fever, and external bleeding.
  • The virus has a fatality rate of up to 88% and is related to Ebola.
  • Reliable reports of suspected cases were received by WHO on January 10, 2025.
  • The outbreak follows a previous incident in Rwanda, where 66 cases and 15 deaths were reported before being declared over on December 20, 2024.
“The samples from two patients were awaiting testing at Tanzania’s national laboratory for confirmation of the outbreak.”

This outbreak is concerning due to the ongoing threat posed by the Marburg virus, highlighting the need for vigilance and swift response in affected regions.
newTitle: Suspected Outbreak of Marburg Virus Claims 8 Lives in Tanzania

title: Study unravels the links between obesity and cancer - News-Medical.Net
summary:
Study Unravels Links Between Obesity and Cancer

Publication Date: 2024
Source: Frontiers of Medicine

Obesity is increasingly recognized as a significant health issue linked to various cancers. This comprehensive review examines the mechanisms through which obesity increases cancer risk and discusses potential clinical implications.

  • Key mechanisms include chronic inflammation, hormonal imbalances, and gut microbiota dysregulation.
  • Chronic low-grade inflammation in adipose tissue is a significant characteristic of obesity influencing cancer development.
  • Hormonal disturbances, particularly in postmenopausal women, contribute to obesity-related cancer risks.
  • Prevention strategies emphasize weight management through diet, exercise, bariatric surgery, and pharmacotherapy.
  • Strategies include dietary modifications and regular physical activity to alleviate inflammation and oxidative stress.
  • The review highlights the need for personalized prevention and treatment strategies.
“A multifaceted approach, combining lifestyle modifications with pharmacological interventions, may be most effective in reducing the incidence of obesity-related cancers.”

In conclusion, understanding the complex links between obesity and cancer can lead to more effective interventions for reducing the burden of obesity-related cancers.
newTitle: Study Unravels Links Between Obesity and Cancer

title: New Obesity Benchmark Adds Body Fat, Organ Health to BMI | Mint - Mint
summary:
New Obesity Benchmark Adds Body Fat, Organ Health to BMI

Publication Date: 2025
Source: Bloomberg

This article reports on a significant shift in how obesity is diagnosed, moving beyond the traditional body mass index (BMI) to include assessments of heart and organ health.

  • The Lancet Diabetes and Endocrinology Commission proposed a new definition for obesity.
  • The new framework considers body fat, organ health, and the ability to perform everyday tasks.
  • This recommendation has been endorsed by 76 organizations, including the World Obesity Federation.
  • Critics of BMI argue that it oversimplifies the complexities of body composition.
  • New obesity drugs are changing the medical perspective on obesity from being a moral failing to a medical condition.
  • Patients will now be classified based on both BMI and additional health indicators.
  • The changes may affect how obesity medications are prescribed.
“BMI contains no information about the functioning of organs,” said Francesco Rubino, commission chair and head of metabolic and bariatric surgery at King’s College London.

This updated approach to diagnosing obesity represents a move toward more personalized healthcare and may reshape treatment protocols.
newTitle: New Obesity Benchmark Adds Body Fat, Organ Health to BMI

title: New Obesity Benchmark Adds Body Fat, Organ Health to BMI - Mint
summary:
New Obesity Benchmark Adds Body Fat, Organ Health to BMI

Publication Date: Recent
Source: Bloomberg

Experts propose a new framework for diagnosing obesity, moving beyond BMI to include body fat measurements and organ health assessments.

  • The Lancet Diabetes and Endocrinology Commission introduced a new obesity definition endorsed by 76 organizations.
  • The recommendation shifts focus towards personalized diagnoses, considering daily functioning and organ health.
  • Current BMI metrics are criticized for being overly simplistic and not differentiating between muscle and fat.
  • New guidelines suggest assessing waist circumference and potential organ dysfunction for obesity classification.
  • The change may impact how obesity drugs are prescribed and patient treatment approaches.
“The commission is re-framing obesity and acknowledges the nuanced reality of obesity,” said Robert Eckel.

Overall, the new benchmark aims for deeper insights into individual health rather than relying solely on BMI.
newTitle: New Obesity Benchmark Adds Body Fat, Organ Health to BMI

title: We are ready: Haryana Health Minister Arti Singh Rao on HMPV scare - mid-day.com
summary:
’We are ready’: Haryana Health Minister Arti Singh Rao on HMPV scare

Publication Date: January 12, 2023 | Source: Mid-Day

As concerns rise over Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV), Haryana Health Minister Arti Singh Rao assured the public that the state is prepared and urged people not to panic.

  • A 10-month-old child was the first reported case of HMPV in Assam.
  • Minister Rao emphasized that the virus is treatable and the situation is under control.
  • She advised the public to maintain hygiene as winter increases pneumonia risks.
  • The World Health Organization noted an increase in respiratory infections during the seasonal trend.
“We are ready. All the districts have been informed to stay alert... I want to request that the people should not be panicked.” - Arti Singh Rao

The emphasis is on preparedness and public awareness to prevent the spread of infections during the winter months.
newTitle: Haryana Health Minister Addresses HMPV Concerns

title: Bird Flu Is Raising Red Flags Among Health Officials - University of Nebraska Medical Center
How to diagnose obesity: Lancet Commission recommends focussing on fat distribution, not just BMI. Here’s why it is significant - The Indian Express
summary:
Lancet Commission Recommends New Approach to Diagnosing Obesity

Date: January 15, 2025 | Source: Indian Express

The Lancet Diabetes & Endocrinology Commission has proposed a new approach to defining and diagnosing obesity, emphasizing the importance of fat distribution rather than solely relying on BMI.

  • The commission consists of 58 experts from various medical fields.
  • It acknowledges that BMI is a useful screening tool but should not be the only method for determining obesity.
  • Recommendations include assessing excess body fat and its distribution through additional measurements such as waist circumference.
  • Experts recommend combining BMI with at least one other body size measurement or using multiple measurements.
"BMI is a helpful screening tool, but it shouldn’t be the sole method."

This new approach aims to provide a more accurate diagnosis of obesity, potentially leading to better health outcomes.
newTitle: Lancet Commission Recommends New Approach to Diagnosing Obesity

title: Does Cancer Always Come Back? What You Should Know About Recurrence - News18
summary:
Does Cancer Always Come Back? What You Should Know About Recurrence

Last Updated: January 15, 2025, 13:26 IST

Cancer recurrence is a common concern among survivors and their loved ones, involving the return of cancer after a period of remission. While not all cancers recur, understanding contributing factors and treatment options is crucial.

  • Cancer recurrence can occur months or years after treatment in various forms - local, regional, or distant.
  • Some cancers, like glioblastoma and epithelial ovarian cancer, have a high recurrence rate.
  • Signs of recurrence can include lumps, sores, weight changes, and fatigue.
  • Precautions to minimize recurrence risk include regular medical follow-ups and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.
  • Treatment for recurrence may involve surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, targeted therapy, or immunotherapy, depending on the cancer type.
“Though cancer doesn’t always return, understanding the factors that contribute to recurrence and being aware of available treatment options is crucial.”

Continued advancements in cancer therapies and proactive health management can help survivors reduce their risk and maintain fulfilling lives after treatment.
newTitle: Understanding Cancer Recurrence: Key Insights and Treatment Options

11 drinks that increase energy levels and alertness instantly - The Times of India
summary:
11 Drinks to Boost Energy and Alertness Instantly

Explore various beverages known to enhance energy levels and alertness effectively in a busy lifestyle.

title: "We are ready": Haryana Health Minister Arti Singh Rao on HMPV - ETHealthWorld
Study identifies 13 genes that increase osteoarthritis risk - R&D World
summary:
Study Identifies 13 Genes Increasing Osteoarthritis Risk

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Cell Genomics

Researchers at the UNC Thurston Arthritis Research Center have identified 13 genes that contribute to osteoarthritis, affecting over 32 million people in the U.S. This discovery aims to guide the development of targeted therapies to prevent disease progression.

  • Researchers pinpointed 13 “high probability risk genes” for osteoarthritis.
  • Nearly half of the risk for osteoarthritis is genetic, according to recent studies.
  • Six of the identified genes were previously unknown.
  • The study was backed by a $2.5 million grant from the National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases.
  • Drug screening studies are being conducted to find compounds that target these genes.
“If we can identify the causal genes, we can use that information to define new genetic targets for therapies for osteoarthritis.” - Dr. Richard F. Loeser, Jr.

This research provides valuable insights into osteoarthritis and could lead to early intervention strategies to combat the disease effectively.
newTitle: Study Identifies 13 Genes Increasing Osteoarthritis Risk

title: Bird Flu Is Raising Red Flags Among Health Officials - Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health
summary:
Bird Flu Is Raising Red Flags Among Health Officials

Publication Date: January 6, 2024 | Source: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

On January 6, Louisiana's Department of Health reported the first U.S. death from H5N1 avian influenza, heightening fears over the virus's potential to mutate and infect humans. Health officials stress the importance of monitoring the situation as cases of H5N1 in humans continue to be documented.

  • The patient had a backyard flock that was exposed to wild birds.
  • 66 confirmed human cases of H5N1 have occurred in the U.S., primarily from poultry farm exposures.
  • Public health experts are monitoring the virus following signs of mutation.
  • The concern of genetic reassortment between seasonal influenza and H5N1 is highlighted.
“We need to double down on our efforts to limit H5N1 transmission among cattle and birds.” - Meghan Davis, DVM, PhD

This situation reflects a larger potential threat to public health, necessitating increased surveillance and precautionary measures.
newTitle: Bird Flu Raises Concerns After First Human Death in the U.S.

title: Hepatitis E vaccination is effective in an epidemic - Science Daily
summary:
Hepatitis E Vaccination is Effective in an Epidemic

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: The Lancet Infectious Diseases

In South Sudan, where hepatitis E outbreaks are common due to contaminated water, a recent study has shown that the two-dose regimen of the hepatitis E vaccine is effective in fighting the disease despite the challenges posed by a 3-dose standard regimen.

  • The study involved collaboration between Médecins Sans Frontières, Johns Hopkins University, the South Sudanese Ministry of Health, WHO, and other organizations.
  • The vaccination campaign targeted over 100,000 people in camps for internally displaced individuals.
  • Results indicated that even after just two doses, the vaccine was effective in reducing hepatitis E cases.
  • Approximately 50,000 deaths worldwide are attributed to hepatitis E annually, with high-risk populations including pregnant women.
  • The WHO has confirmed the effectiveness of the vaccine and approved the creation of a global stockpile for emergencies.
"Our results combined with others helped lead to recent approval by WHO's International Coordinating Group of a stockpile of hepatitis E vaccines for emergencies." - Andrew Azman, Epidemiologist

In conclusion, the study supports the vaccine's use in outbreak situations and showcases the importance of adapting vaccination protocols to address immediate health crises.
newTitle: Hepatitis E Vaccination Proves Effective in Epidemics

title: Outbreak of suspected Marburg Virus Disease - United Republic of Tanzania - ReliefWeb
summary:
Outbreak of Suspected Marburg Virus Disease in Tanzania

Date: 13 January 2025 Source: World Health Organization

On 13 January 2025, the WHO reported an outbreak of suspected Marburg Virus Disease in the Kagera region of Tanzania, with initial reports indicating a high case fatality rate among suspected cases.

  • Six suspected cases were reported, with five fatalities.
  • By 11 January 2025, nine suspected cases were identified, with eight deaths (CFR of 89%).
  • National rapid response teams have been deployed to undertake contact tracing and investigation.
  • The outbreak has raised concerns due to the risk of nosocomial transmission among healthcare workers.
  • The geographic spread poses concerns, particularly near international borders with several neighboring countries.
  • WHO assesses the risk of the outbreak as high nationally but low globally at this stage.

The suspected outbreak thus far involves at least nine suspected cases, including eight deaths, resulting in a high CFR of 89%.

Enhanced surveillance, risk communication, and community engagement are essential to manage this outbreak effectively. WHO advises against travel restrictions with Tanzania.
newTitle: Outbreak of Suspected Marburg Virus Disease in Tanzania

title: Tanzania: Confirmed Marburg Virus Outbreak Kills 8 - Details - Times Now
summary:
Tanzania: Confirmed Marburg Virus Outbreak Kills 8

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: World Health Organization

A Marburg virus epidemic in Tanzania has led to eight deaths, with nine confirmed cases reported by the World Health Organization.

  • The outbreak is the second recent incident of Marburg virus in Tanzania following a previous outbreak announced in March 2023.
  • Collaboration exists between Tanzania's Ministry of Health and global health organizations like the CDC and WHO for epidemic response.
  • The WHO warns that improving disease surveillance may reveal more cases in the coming days.
  • Global health experts emphasize the need for enhanced surveillance to prevent further spread.
“We would expect further cases in coming days as disease surveillance improves.” - Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General

This latest outbreak underscores the ongoing risks zoonotic diseases pose to global health.
newTitle: Tanzania Faces Marburg Virus Outbreak with 8 Fatalities

BMI by itself isn't an accurate tool to diagnose obesity: Study - The Times of India
summary:
BMI by itself isn't an accurate tool to diagnose obesity: Study

Date: October 2023

Source: Health Wellness Journal

This article discusses a study that challenges the effectiveness of Body Mass Index (BMI) as a tool for diagnosing obesity.

  • The study suggests BMI alone does not accurately reflect an individual's health.
  • Experts recommend combining BMI with other assessments for a comprehensive view.
  • There is a growing call for more reliable measurement tools in obesity diagnoses.
"BMI is a simplistic measure that doesn't account for muscle mass, fat distribution, and other health markers."

Ultimately, the article emphasizes the need for a multifaceted approach in assessing obesity rather than relying solely on BMI.
newTitle: BMI by itself isn't an accurate tool to diagnose obesity: Study

title: Role of Zinc, Copper, and Vitamin D in Alopecia Areata Explored - Dermatology Times
summary:
Role of Zinc, Copper, and Vitamin D in Alopecia Areata Explored

Publication Date: May 2024 | Source: Dermatology Times

The analysis findings support the potential use of zinc and vitamin D supplementation in managing alopecia areata.

  • Alopecia areata (AA) affects 0.5% to 2% of the global population, with significant psychological impacts.
  • Vitamin D deficiency is associated with increased AA risk, as shown in a meta-analysis indicating lower serum levels in AA patients.
  • Zinc levels are also significantly lower in patients with AA, supporting its role in hair follicle health.
  • The role of copper remains inconclusive, with studies showing mixed results regarding its serum levels.
  • Further research is needed to establish causal relationships and improve treatment strategies.
“Deficiencies in vitamin D and zinc are significant risk factors for AA, warranting further investigation.”

The findings underscore the importance of nutritional assessments in managing alopecia areata.
newTitle: Role of Zinc, Copper, and Vitamin D in Alopecia Areata Explored

title: Moderna May Have The Best Shot At A Vaccine For Stomach Flu - Forbes
summary:
Moderna May Have The Best Shot At A Vaccine For Stomach Flu

Date: Not specified | Source: Forbes

Every year, between 19 and 21 million Americans suffer from gastroenteritis caused by noroviruses. Norovirus infections lead to numerous hospitalizations, and with a recent surge in cases, vaccination efforts are becoming crucial.

  • Norovirus causes hundreds of thousands of ER visits and about 900 deaths annually in the U.S.
  • Moderna is currently at the forefront, utilizing mRNA technology similar to its Covid-19 vaccine.
  • The economic impact of annual norovirus infections is around $60 billion globally.
  • Moderna's norovirus vaccine aims to target three different strains, potentially covering up to 80% of yearly outbreaks.
  • Challenges in vaccine development include the need for effective immunity in the gastrointestinal tract.
“Washing your hands with soap and water is the most important thing in protecting yourself.” - Daniel Kuritzkes

The potential for a successful norovirus vaccine could revolutionize public health and reduce the substantial economic burden of the virus, although challenges remain in vaccine development and testing.
newTitle: Moderna Leads the Charge in Developing a Norovirus Vaccine

title: Norovirus wave in US more than double last year's peak as new strain fuels winter surge: CDC data - India Today
summary:
Norovirus wave in US more than double last year's peak as new strain fuels winter surge: CDC data

Published On: Jan 15, 2025

Source: indiastodayglobal

Norovirus cases have surged to more than double last year's peak, primarily due to a new strain, GII.17[P17], with the Midwest being the hardest hit. Experts are urging precautions as infection rates rise.

  • Norovirus positivity rate has jumped to nearly 28% during the New Year’s holidays, compared to 13.52% last year.
  • The CDC reports that norovirus is widespread across all U.S. regions, particularly affecting the Midwest from Kansas to Michigan.
  • The new strain, GII.17[P17], is responsible for over 70% of current outbreaks, including incidents on cruise ships.
  • Precautions include frequent handwashing and avoiding contaminated food and water.
“This new strain has caused over 70% of outbreaks this season, and lower immunity to it is believed to be driving the current surge,” experts say.

The current surge in norovirus cases is raising concerns, and CDC recommends following health precautions to mitigate the spread.
newTitle: Norovirus Wave in U.S. Doubles Last Year's Peak Due to New Strain

title: Are children getting sick and dying due to chemicals and plastics? Scientists reveal the truth - MSN
Broken Heart Disease: How heightened stress-levels can weaken heart muscles - The Times of India
summary:
Broken Heart Disease: How Heightened Stress Levels Can Weaken Heart Muscles

Publication Date: October 17, 2023, Source: Times of India

Heart disease can sometimes be triggered by emotional events, commonly referred to as broken heart syndrome. This article discusses how significant stress can lead to heart muscle weakening.

  • Heightened stress levels can lead to temporary weakening of the heart muscles, mimicking heart attack symptoms.
  • Recent studies indicate a link between emotional trauma and heart health, particularly in vulnerable populations.
  • Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, and other common heart attack indicators.
  • Understanding this phenomenon is crucial for better diagnostic practices in cardiology.
“Understanding the emotional triggers and their physiological impact on the heart is essential for preventing serious complications.”

This article emphasizes the necessity for increased awareness surrounding emotional factors that can affect heart health.
newTitle: Broken Heart Disease: How Heightened Stress Levels Can Weaken Heart Muscles

title: Addressing the controversial 'O': All you need to know about Ozempic and why it’s trending - The Times of India
summary:
Addressing the controversial 'O': All you need to know about Ozempic and why it’s trending

Publication Date: (not specified) Source: Times of India

Ozempic is trending due to its growing popularity and discussions around its efficacy and side effects. This article explores why it has become a focal point of conversation.

  • Ozempic is widely used as a weight-loss drug.
  • It is often prescribed for diabetes management.
  • Concerns about its side effects and long-term health implications are rising.
  • The drug has sparked conversations about obesity treatment options.
"Ozempic is changing the landscape of weight management and diabetes treatment, but it comes with both praise and caution."

The rise of Ozempic in public discourse highlights the shifting attitudes toward weight loss drugs and their perceived benefits versus risks.
newTitle: Addressing the controversial 'O': All you need to know about Ozempic and why it’s trending

title: Are children getting sick and dying due to chemicals and plastics? Scientists reveal the truth - The Times of India
summary:
Are Children at Risk from Chemicals and Plastics? Insights from Leading Scientists

Publication Date: Recent | Source: The Guardian

This article discusses the alarming rise in diseases among children, attributed to increasing exposure to synthetic chemicals and plastics, as highlighted by a new study published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

  • Children are more sensitive to chemicals due to physiological factors.
  • Deaths from noncommunicable diseases have drastically increased over the past 50 years.
  • Childhood cancer rates have surged by 35%.
  • One in 36 children is diagnosed with autism.
  • Asthma cases have tripled, and obesity rates have quadrupled.
  • Manufacturing of plastics has increased 50 times since 1950.
“The evidence is so overwhelming and the effects of manufactured chemicals are so disruptive for children, that inaction is no longer an option.” - Daniele Mandrioli

The authors call for urgent global action to reform chemical testing and manufacturing practices to better protect children's health.
newTitle: Are Children at Risk from Chemicals and Plastics? Insights from Leading Scientists
